010package imagingbook.lib.math;
011
012//import imagingbook.lib.math.Matrix;
013//import imagingbook.lib.settings.PrintPrecision;
014
015/**
016 * Implements an efficient, closed form algorithm for calculating the real 
017 * eigenvalues (&lambda;) and eigenvectors (x) of a 2x2 matrix M of the form
018 * <pre>
019 *   | A B |
020 *   | C D | </pre>
021 * There are typically (but not in general) two pairs of real-valued 
022 * solutions 
023 * &lang;&lambda;<sub>1</sub>, x<sub>1</sub>&rang;,
024 * &lang;&lambda;<sub>2</sub>, x<sub>2</sub>&rang;
025 * such that M&middot;x<sub>k</sub> = &lambda;<sub>k</sub>&middot;x<sub>k</sub>.
026 * <p>
027 * This implementation is inspired by Blinn, Jim: "Jim Blinn's Corner: 
028 * Notation, Notation, Notation", Morgan Kaufmann (2002) -
029 * Ch. 5 ("Consider the Lowly 2x2 Matrix").
030 * Note that Blinn uses the (common computer graphics) notation 
031 * x&middot;M = &lambda;&middot;x,
032 * while this implementation adopts the notation 
033 * M&middot;x = &lambda;&middot;x, 
034 * i.e., the matrix M is transposed (elements B/C are exchanged).
035 * </p>
036 * 
037 * @author W. Burger
038 * @version 2020-02-09
039 */
040public class Eigensolver2x2 {
041        
042        private final boolean isReal;
043        private final double[] eVals = {Double.NaN, Double.NaN};
044        private final double[][] eVecs = new double[2][];
045        
046        /**
047         * Constructor, takes a 2x2 matrix.
048         * @param M a 2x2 matrix
049         */
050        public Eigensolver2x2(double[][] M) {
051                this(M[0][0], M[0][1], M[1][0], M[1][1]);
052        }
053        
054        /**
055         * Constructor, takes the individual elements of a 2x2 matrix.
056         * @param A matrix element M[0,0]
057         * @param B matrix element M[0,1]
058         * @param C matrix element M[1,0]
059         * @param D matrix element M[1,1]
060         */
061        public Eigensolver2x2(double A, double B, double C, double D) {
062                isReal = solve(A, B, C, D);
063        }
064        
065        private boolean solve(double A, double B, double C, double D) {
066                final double R = (A + D) / 2;
067                final double S = (A - D) / 2;
068                final double rho = S * S + B * C;
069                
070                if (rho < 0) {  // no real-valued eigenvalues
071                        return false;
072                }
073                
074                final double T = Math.sqrt(rho);
075                eVals[0] = R + T;
076                eVals[1] = R - T;
077                if (A - D > 0) {
078                        eVecs[0] = new double[] { S + T, C };
079                        eVecs[1] = new double[] { B, -S - T };
080                }
081                else if (A - D < 0) {
082                        eVecs[0] = new double[] { B, -S + T};
083                        eVecs[1] = new double[] { S - T, C};
084                }
085                else {          // (A - D) == 0
086                        
087                        final double aB = Math.abs(B);
088                        final double aC = Math.abs(C);
089                        final double sBC = Math.sqrt(B * C);
090                        if (aB < aC) {                                                  // |B| < |C|
091                                eVecs[0] = new double[] { sBC, C};
092                                eVecs[1] = new double[] {-sBC, C};
093                        }
094                        else if (aB > aC) {                                     // |B| > |C|
095                                eVecs[0] = new double[] { B,  sBC};
096                                eVecs[1] = new double[] { B, -sBC};
097                        }
098                        else {                                                                  // |B| == |C|
099                                eVecs[0] = new double[] { C, C};
100                                eVecs[1] = new double[] {-C, C};
101                        }
102                }
103                return true;
104        }
105        
106        /**
107         * Returns {@code true} iff the associated matrix has real 
108         * eigenvalues.
109         * @return as described
110         */
111        public boolean isReal() {
112                return isReal;
113        }
114        
115        /**
116         * Returns a vector holding the two real eigenvalues. Both are
117         * {@code NaN} if the associated matrix has no real eigenvalues.
118         * The first eigenvalue is the greater of the two.
119         * Note that the method returns a reference to an internal
120         * array and should thus be used read-only!
121         * @return a 2-element array of eigenvalues
122         */
123        public double[] getEigenvalues() {
124                return this.eVals;
125        }
126        
127        /**
128         * Returns a 2x2 array holding the two real eigenvectors.
129         * When used in the form
130         * <pre>double[][] X = getEigenvalues();</pre>
131         * then {@code X[0]} and {@code X[1]} contain the 1st and 2nd eigenvector,
132         * respectively. If the associated matrix has no real eigenvalues,
133         * then {@code X[0]} and {@code X[1]} are both {@code null}.
134         * Otherwise {@code X[k][0]} and {@code X[k][1]} are the x/y components
135         * of the k-th eigenvector.
136         * The ordering of the returned eigenvectors is the same as for the
137         * eigenvalues returned by {@link #getEigenvalues()}.
138         * Note that the method returns a reference to an internal
139         * array and should thus be used read-only!
140         * @return a 2-element array of 2D eigenvectors
141         */
142        public double[][] getEigenvectors() {
143                return this.eVecs;
144        }
145                
146        // for Testing only --------------------------------------------------------------
